content.title: Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP)
content.summary: Acute infection of the lung parenchyma acquired outside of hospital or healthcare settings
key_points: Most common pathogens: S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, atypicals
Severity assessment: PSI/PORT score or CURB-65
Outpatient: amoxicillin or doxycycline; if comorbid: respiratory FQ or beta-lactam + macrolide
Inpatient: beta-lactam (ceftriaxone) + macrolide or respiratory FQ alone
MRSA/Pseudomonas coverage only with specific risk factors
5-7 day duration adequate if clinical improvement

statement.text: Community-acquired pneumonia is an acute infection of the pulmonary parenchyma in a patient not recently hospitalized or residing in a long-term care facility. Diagnosis requires clinical symptoms plus radiographic infiltrate. Empiric antibiotic selection is based on severity and comorbidities.
statement.formal: CAP = Clinical features (cough, fever, dyspnea) + Radiographic infiltrate + Severity assessment → Empiric antibiotics targeting likely pathogens

explanation.intuition: Pneumonia is an infection filling the air sacs (alveoli) with pus and fluid, blocking oxygen exchange. The body responds with fever, cough, and increased breathing rate. Treatment with appropriate antibiotics clears the infection.
explanation.key_insight: Most CAP is caused by S. pneumoniae and atypical organisms. Empiric therapy must cover both. Don't add MRSA/Pseudomonas coverage unless specific risk factors present - this causes antibiotic resistance without benefit.

definitions_glossary.CURB_65: Severity score: Confusion, Urea >7, Resp rate ≥30, BP <90/60, age ≥65
definitions_glossary.PSI_PORT: Pneumonia Severity Index - predicts mortality, determines site of care
definitions_glossary.typical_pathogens: S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, M. catarrhalis
definitions_glossary.atypical_pathogens: Mycoplasma, Chlamydophila, Legionella - intracellular, require macrolide/FQ
definitions_glossary.consolidation: Airspace filling with inflammatory exudate visible on imaging
definitions_glossary.lobar_pneumonia: Infection limited to one lobe, typically bacterial
definitions_glossary.bronchopneumonia: Patchy infiltrates in multiple areas, often from bronchial spread
definitions_glossary.walking_pneumonia: Mild CAP, often atypical, ambulatory treatment
definitions_glossary.empyema: Pus in pleural space - complication of pneumonia

pathophysiology.mechanism: Aspiration or inhalation of pathogens → colonization of lower respiratory tract → alveolar invasion → inflammatory response → exudate filling alveoli → impaired gas exchange
pathophysiology.host_defenses: Cough reflex, mucociliary clearance, alveolar macrophages, IgA. Failure of defenses (smoking, aspiration, immunocompromise) increases risk.

diagnostic_criteria.imaging: CXR with new infiltrate confirms diagnosis; CT if CXR unclear

special_pathogens.MRSA_risk_factors: Prior MRSA, IV drug use, severe necrotizing - add vancomycin/linezolid

definition.@value: Acute lower respiratory tract infection with pulmonary infiltrate acquired outside of hospital or healthcare settings

learning_objectives: Select empiric antibiotics based on setting and severity
Identify indications for MRSA and Pseudomonas coverage
clinical_pearls: Procalcitonin can help differentiate bacterial from viral - may guide antibiotic duration
5 days is adequate if afebrile 48h and clinically stable
Don't add MRSA/Pseudomonas coverage without specific risk factors
Respiratory FQ are overprescribed - reserve for penicillin allergy or comorbidities
Legionella: think of it with GI symptoms, hyponatremia, CNS symptoms

sources.source: Metlay JP, et al. Diagnosis and Treatment of Adults with CAP. Am J Respir Crit Care Med 2019
